title: Argumentation and Debate
description: Constructing and defending academic arguments in formal discussions

exercises.title: Building an Academic Argument
exercises.instruction: Use the following framework to construct a 2-minute argument on the given topic
exercises.topic: Universities should prioritize practical vocational training over traditional liberal arts education.
framework: Provide your strongest supporting point with evidence
usefulPhrases: However, this overlooks the fact that...
In conclusion, it is clear that...
exercises.modelResponse: I would argue that universities should maintain a balance between vocational training and liberal arts education, rather than prioritizing one over the other. The evidence suggests that liberal arts education develops critical thinking and adaptability—skills increasingly valued in a rapidly changing job market. While some might contend that vocational training offers more immediate employability, this overlooks the fact that many technical skills become obsolete quickly, whereas foundational analytical abilities remain relevant throughout one's career. In conclusion, a holistic approach that integrates both practical skills and theoretical foundations best prepares students for long-term success.

exercises.title: Responding to Counterarguments
exercises.instruction: Read the argument below and prepare a 1-minute rebuttal
exercises.argument: Social media has fundamentally damaged interpersonal communication. People spend more time looking at screens than engaging in meaningful face-to-face interactions, leading to increased isolation and superficial relationships.
responsePrompts: What assumption in this argument can you challenge?
What nuance does this argument overlook?
usefulPhrases: This argument rests on the questionable assumption that...
While there is some validity to this claim, it fails to account for...
The evidence actually points to a more complex picture...

exercises.title: Moderating Academic Discourse
exercises.instruction: Practice using these phrases to facilitate a balanced discussion
exercises.scenario: You are moderating a panel on climate policy. One panelist has been dominating the conversation.

transitioning: That's an important point. Let's now hear from Dr. Kim on this matter.
Building on that perspective, I'd like to invite an alternative viewpoint.
synthesizing: So, if I understand correctly, we have two competing considerations here...
It seems we're grappling with a fundamental tension between...
redirecting: That's a valuable contribution. Perhaps we could also examine...
I'd like us to return to the central question of...
concluding: In light of our discussion, what key takeaways can we identify?
What areas of consensus have emerged from this exchange?

exercises.title: Quick Response Exercise
exercises.instruction: Prepare a 30-second response to each prompt, using hedging language appropriately
prompts: What role should technology play in education?
Is economic growth compatible with environmental sustainability?
Should voting be mandatory in democratic societies?
hedgingPhrases: There appears to be evidence suggesting...
This is, of course, a nuanced issue, but...

pronunciationFocus.note: Stress on first syllable; the 'u' is a schwa
Compound stress pattern; primary stress on 'coun-'
Stress on second syllable; 'th' is voiceless
